title: Technology Intervention to Support Caregiving for Alzheimer's Disease (I-CARE)
description_brief: The specific aims of this study are 1) to test the trial and intervention feasibility of Brain Care Notes (BCN) app, 2) To estimate the effect size of BCN on reducing informal caregiver burden at 6 months, and 3) To estimate the effect size of BCN on reducing patient behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD) at 6 months. Subjects will be recruited from the Aging Brain Care (ABC) program of Eskenazi Health and Indiana University Health located in central Indiana.
description_detailed:
Informal caregivers of patients with Alzheimer's disease and related dementia (ADRD) manage a complex spectrum of patient behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD). BPSD are major contributing factors to caregivers' burden and adverse health outcomes, leading to an increase of unplanned hospitalizations and a decrease in quality of life. The National Alzheimer's Project Act recognizes the need for interventions that "enable family caregivers to continue to provide care while maintaining their own health and well-being." Furthermore, recommendations from 2015 and 2018 Alzheimer's Disease Research Summits include the application of technology to improve caregiving research and ADRD care

This pilot randomized controlled trial, will test the feasibility and estimate the effect size of integrating mobile health technology BrainCare Notes (BCN) into an existing, fully operational, and self-sustaining clinical program (Aging Brain Care; ABC) and IU Health primary care physician clinics (IUHP). BCN is a mobile application (app) for informal caregivers of patients with Alzheimer's Disease and related dementia (ADRD). The BCN app delivers 24/7 psychoeducation and caregiver support, assessment of informal caregiver status and patients' behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD), and engagement tools for self-management and communication. Over a 15 month accrual period, we propose to enroll from the ABC clinical program and IUHP 60 dyads consisting of an adult patient with ADRD and one (primary) informal caregiver. The intervention will continue for 6 months and final assessments will be completed at 6 months. Feasibility data will be collected throughout the study and assessed at the end of the study by computing: (a) recruitment rate; (b) data completion; (c) BCN usability; (d) BCN acceptance; and (e) BCN use. Caregiver burden and patient BPSD will be collected at baseline, 3, and 6 months and evaluated for changes from baseline to 6 months in each group. Means, standard deviations, and confidence intervals will be computed to test feasibility hypotheses. Mixed linear models will be used to test hypotheses comparing the two conditions at 6 months.

groups.title: Usual Care
groups.description:
Dyads of informal caregivers plus patients randomized to the comparison group receive usual care for Alzheimer's disease and related dementia (ADRD) from their health system, either Eskenazi Health or Indiana University (IU) Health.

The standard of ADRD care at Eskenazi Health is the ABC Clinical Program. The goal of the ABC Clinical Program is to help primary care physicians achieve the standard of care in the diagnosis, evaluation and management of patients with ADRD. It is delivered by an interdisciplinary team led by a care coordinator. The informal caregiver of the person living is also enrolled in the program and caregiver burden is assessed and managed. The ABC team collects all relevant data and formulates an individualized care plan in collaboration with the informal caregiver. The care coordinator communicates the team's recommendations to the primary care physician and finalizes a collaborative plan of action. During the next year, the ABC team uses face-to-face and telephone interactions with the patient and caregiver to monitor and modify implementation of the care plan.

The standard of ADRD care at IU Health is Primary Care visits. The goal of Primary Care at IU Health is to provide preventive care services to their patients. Older adults are assessed for ADRD during clinic visits and referred to brain care specialty as necessary.

groups.title: Brain CareNotes (BCN) Software

measures.description: Participants were asked to rate their need for help reading heath information on a five-point scale (Never, Rarely, Sometimes, Often, Always)

outcomeMeasures.title: Feasibility: Recruitment Rate
outcomeMeasures.description: Recruitment rate is the average monthly rate of recruitment into the study, calculated as participants recruited over the accrual period.

groups.title: All Participants
groups.description: All participants, prior to assignment to condition

outcomeMeasures.title: Feasibility: Data Completeness
outcomeMeasures.description: Data completeness is the number of enrolled and randomized individuals who provided data at 3 and 6 months.

groups.title: Brain CareNotes (BCN) Software

outcomeMeasures.title: Feasibility: BCN Usability (3 Months)
outcomeMeasures.description: BCN usability at 3 months is the summary score on the modified System Usability Scale (SUS) 10-item scale instrument, ranging from 0 (worst outcome) to 100 (best outcome).

groups.title: Brain CareNotes (BCN) Software App
groups.description: Participants allocated to the BCN app intervention

outcomeMeasures.title: Feasibility: BCN Usability (6 Months)
outcomeMeasures.description: BCN usability at 6 months is the summary score on the modified System Usability Scale (SUS) 10-item scale instrument, ranging from 0 to 100. Higher scores indicate higher usability.

groups.title: Brain CareNotes (BCN) Software App
groups.description: Participants allocated to the BCN app intervention

outcomeMeasures.title: Feasibility: BCN Acceptance (3 Months)
outcomeMeasures.description: Acceptance at 3 months is the mean score on the Behavioral Intention 4-item scale on a 7-point response scale from 0 (not at all) to 6 (a great deal). Higher scores indicate higher acceptance.

groups.title: Brain CareNotes (BCN) Software App
groups.description: Participants allocated to the BCN app intervention

outcomeMeasures.title: Feasibility: BCN Acceptance (6 Months)
outcomeMeasures.description: Acceptance at 6 months is the mean score on the Behavioral Intention 4-item scale on a 7-point response scale from 0 (not at all) to 6 (a great deal).

groups.title: Brain CareNotes (BCN) Software App
groups.description: Participants allocated to the BCN app intervention

outcomeMeasures.title: Caregiver Burden (Baseline)
outcomeMeasures.description: Informal caregiver burden at baseline, assessed by calculating the NPI-Caregiver Distress score (possible range from 0, best outcome, to 60, worst outcome) from the researcher administered Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI)

outcomeMeasures.title: BPSD Severity (Baseline)
outcomeMeasures.description: Severity of patient behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD) at baseline, assessed by calculating the NPI total score (possible range from 0, best outcome, to 144, worst outcome) from caregiver-reported responses to the researcher-administered Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI).

eventGroups.title: Brain CareNotes (BCN) Software - Patients

limitationsAndCaveats.description:
BCN usage (a primary feasibility outcome) continues to be analyzed and data are not reported.

Data are reported from consented informal caregivers only. Caregivers provided data on themselves and the patient.

Data on secondary outcomes of Caregiver Burden and Patient Symptom Severity were imputed for all randomized participants.

Acute care utilization data combine emergency room (ER) and hospital based admissions.

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is a mobile telehealth/caregiver support application (Brain CareNotes, BCN) intended to reduce caregiver burden and to reduce patient behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD), i.e., neuropsychiatric symptoms rather than a pharmacologic disease-modifying approach. citeturn0search6turn0search1

Act: Key extracted details — Intervention: Brain CareNotes (BCN) mobile app (telehealth) used with caregiver–patient dyads; Primary aims: feasibility of the app and estimating effect size on reducing informal caregiver burden and reducing patient BPSD at 6 months; Trial type: non‑pharmacological behavioral/technology intervention (no drug). citeturn0search0turn0search6

Reflect: Classification check — This is not a biologic or small molecule, nor a cognitive‑enhancer drug. Its target is management/reduction of neuropsychiatric (behavioral and psychological) symptoms and caregiver burden via a caregiving/telehealth intervention, so it best fits the 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement' category. Trial registration and publications describing these aims: protocol and pilot results. citeturn0search6turn0search1
explanation_agent: Reason: The described intervention is a mobile telehealth / caregiver-support application (Brain CareNotes, BCN) designed to reduce caregiver burden and behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD). This is a non‑pharmacological, behavioral/technology approach that does not act on a molecular, genetic, or biological pathway targeted by CADRO categories A–Q or R. citeturn0search1turn0search3turn0search6

Act: Key extracted details — Intervention: Brain CareNotes (BCN) mobile app used with caregiver–patient dyads; Primary aims: feasibility/usability and estimating effect size on reducing informal caregiver burden and patient BPSD at follow‑up; Trial type: non‑pharmacological behavioral/technology intervention (no drug or biologic is tested). These trial facts are described in the protocol and pilot/effectiveness reports. citeturn0search1turn0search3turn0search0

Reflect: CADRO categories classify therapeutic targets (e.g., amyloid, tau, inflammation, synaptic function). Because this trial tests a caregiving/telehealth intervention (management of neuropsychiatric symptoms and caregiver burden) rather than a biological or pharmacologic target, the appropriate CADRO mapping is 'T) Other'. Web sources used to verify the trial description and aims are cited above. citeturn0search1turn0search3turn0search5
